column4: I have a usb hard drive that shows up in gparted as being completely unallocated, but it mounts just fine as a fat32 partition, I am confused as all hell, any suggestions on how to reconcile the differences?
how can that be? it is fat32?
what's the corresponding line in the output of 'mount'?
did you start gparted with gksudo?
yeah, I chose it from the administration menu
does 'sudo cfdisk /dev/sdb' show a partition table?
so cfdisk sees the partition table, but gparted doesn't -- that's strange
what were you going to do with gparted on this drive?
what I find stranger is that cfdisk says it is a 'linux' partition, but mount claims to have mounted it as vfat
actually I was trying to figure out why it wouldn't mount in windows
because windows has... nothing for tools in that regard
trust mount. What cfdisk shows is just a label. If you change the label to 0b or 0c, it will mount in Windows.
hit 't' in cfdisk to change the partition type, then select 0c (probably), then write and reboot.
